A communication transmitted from Yi-An Huang, City Manager, relative to Awaiting Report Item Number 24-26, regarding clarification on the Wage Theft Ordinance.

Body

 

 

 

To the Honorable, the City Council:

 

In response to Awaiting Report AR-24-26 the City Manager provides the following response and requests that this report be forwarded to the Ordinance Committee for further consideration:

 

On Monday October 17th 2022 the City of Cambridge City Council ordained  the Wage Theft Ordinance providing the City with the authority to deny or revoke any license or permit, if during the three year period prior to an application, a license or permit applicant committed or attempted to commit a violation of federal or state wage laws regulating payment associated with work done by employees of a license or permit applicant or any sub-contractors hired by the applicant.

 

The ordinance further requires a Wage Theft Enforcement Committee (WTEC) be established by the City Manager with the approval of City Council. The charge of the WTEC is to review wage theft complaints, filed with the City Manager, and to provide advice related to the implementation of the ordinance.

 

There is strong alignment with City Council in support of workers employed in various jobs across the city and ensuring, as best provided by our laws, that people are working in a safe environment where they are treated properly and where they are appropriately compensated in a timely manner for their labor. While our overall goals are the same, it is of concern that the present ordinance may not be enforceable in a number of the areas, as was intended when first ordained.

   

Primary among concerns is the issue of a preemption specific to those licenses and permits, where the authority is derived directly from the state and the courts have held that local requirements concerning those licenses and permits is in conflict with the state statutory scheme.  The second concern relates to additional punishments or effective reconsideration of a wage theft violation of federal or state law where the federal government or a state authority has already issued a debarment or other sanction relative to that law against a contractor or her/his subcontractors. A reasonable presumption, in those instances would be that if the violation has already been dealt with by a federal or state conviction and/or penalty, adding an additional punishment, by denying a license or permit, at the local level, after the debarment has been served may not be justifiable.

 

The City of Cambridge, through its various departments and commissions issues thousands of licenses and permits on an annual basis to various entities operating across the city. The nature of these permits is multivarious: from the one-day alcohol licenses associated with community events to building permits associated with multi-million dollar building projects.

 

 

 

 

 

While many permits are issued based on authority granted to departments by City ordinances, there are numerous instances where the authority associated with various licenses and permits is based on authority derived directly from state law and is prescribed by detailed state regulations, where the discretion afforded the municipal authority is strictly limited. The following are two significant examples where the City’s authority is limited and does not extend to rejecting or suspending licenses or permits associated with work applications that come before the City based on wage theft.

 

·         The Inspectional Services Department (ISD) issues approximately 2,000 permits every year. The permits issued by ISD are primarily those required to ensure compliance with the State of Massachusetts Building, Plumbing and Gas, Electrical, Mechanical and Sanitary Codes.  The authority provided to the Commissioner of Inspectional Services as the City’s Building Inspector is derived directly from the state. The Commissioner for Inspectional Services does not have the authority to deny these permits based on the City of Cambridge Wage Theft Ordinance.

 

·         The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities is the primary regulatory authority associated with gas and electrical companies in the state. The City has the authority to reject or require modifications to permit applications and licenses for utility work through its Pole and Conduit Commission or through the Department of Public Works based on technical and safety related concerns.  Neither the Pole and Conduit Commission nor the Department of Public Works has the authority to reject permit requests based on previous or current failures associated with payment of wages to employees by companies doing construction work for these utility companies.

 

The License Commission of the City of Cambridge is a three-person commission consisting of the Chair, the Police Commissioner and the Fire Chief. The License Commission issues a broad variety of Licenses for activities throughout the city on an annual basis. The Licenses span everything from hawker/peddler licenses to entertainment licenses and licenses associated with alcohol sales and consumption.  The authority afforded the License Commission is relatively broad, providing discretion to the Commissioners to deny an application based on character of the applicant (as well as other factors). However, considering the City ordinance as presently ordained, some of that discretion, in response to previously adjudicated federal or state wage theft cases is removed most particularly in Section 2.66120, Paragraph (d) where a period of revocation or non-renewal is definitively identified as one year, thereby prohibiting a conciliation process to resolve outstanding wage theft issues. This mandatory requirement also limits other permitting departments in how they deal with applicants with prior or ongoing wage theft violations.

 

Various forms of wage theft ordinance exist in cities across the state. We have examined five cities where wage theft ordinances are in place: Somerville, Lawrence, Framingham, Worcester and Salem. Please see the attached spreadsheet. The details associated with the ordinances vary considerably from one community to another. In some communities the ordinance only applies to municipal contracts and to projects where tax relief agreements exist between cities and property developers (Framingham and Worcester). In others, the authority extends to those businesses who seek licenses from city government (Salem). In Somerville, the ordinance is written such that it applies to Licenses, Major building construction permits associated with commercial buildings, projects where tax relief agreements are agreed to and finally to City contracts associated with RFPs and construction projects.  

 

The City of Cambridge ordinance is unique in that it extends the authority to all licenses and permits issued by the City.  Our ordinance is also unique in that it does not directly apply to city projects.  However, it should be noted that in 2016 the then City Manager signed an executive order establishing certification requirements for all contractors and vendors bidding on City of Cambridge contracts. Under the executive order, those bidding on city contracts are required to certify their compliance with federal and state wage law with the city. The executive order also prohibits city departments from contracting with debarred vendors for the period of their debarment. This ensures that city resources are not used to support those vendors debarred for wage law violations. In instances where vendors have violations within the previous three years, they are required to disclose them and provide a wage bond for the duration of the contract that they have been selected to execute.  This executive order requirement has been successfully enforced since 2016. Former Mayor Walsh signed a similar executive order in Boston in 2014.  Having City contractors and City vendors subject to the City wage theft ordinance would further reinforce this requirement.

 

The City of Somerville (11-person) and the City of Framingham (7-person) ordinances require that Wage Theft Advisory Committee’s be established. The function of these committees is to assist employees affected by wage theft. The City of Cambridge ordinance calls for an 11-person Wage Theft Enforcement Committee and the role of the committee is like that which is called for in both Somerville and Framingham. However, given the concerns relative to the scope of the City of Cambridge ordinance and the concerns relative to the extent to which enforcement can be authorized and alternative resolution processes can be incorporated, it is recommended that these concerns be resolved prior to the formation of a Wage Theft Enforcement Committee.   

 

In summary, we request that the Wage Theft Ordinance be returned to the Ordinance Committee for additional consideration. Staff propose that amendments to the ordinance be considered in a variety of areas to include:

·         The removal of those provisions where the City’s does not have the authority to reject, terminate or suspend licenses and permits.

·         To include provisions related to wage theft for City contracts and to include a provision where a wage bond can be required to ensure workers have an alternative means of obtaining compensation in instances where wage theft has occurred.

·         To provide authority to the City Manager to promulgate regulations in support of the ordinance.

·         To provide for an appeal or conciliation process for those who have violated the Wage Theft ordinance.

 

Drafts of proposed amendments would be provided to the Council for referral to the Ordinance Committee at the Ordinance Committee hearing to allow full consideration of such in advance of committee discussion.  Your consideration is greatly appreciated.

 

Very truly yours,

 

Yi-An Huang

City Manager
